funder.name: National Natural Science Foundation of China
Natural Science Foundation of Shandong Province

message.abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Oxidation of renewable polyol/sugar into formic acid using molecular O<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> over heterogeneous catalysts is still challenging due to the insufficient activation of both O<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> and organic substrates on coordination-saturated metal oxides. In this study, we develop a defective MnO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> catalyst through a coordination number reduction strategy to enhance the aerobic oxidation of various polyols/sugars to formic acid. Compared to common MnO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, the tri-coordinated Mn in the defective MnO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> catalyst displays the electronic reconstruction of surface oxygen charge state and rich surface oxygen vacancies. These oxygen vacancies create more Mn<jats:sup>δ+</jats:sup> Lewis acid site together with nearby oxygen as Lewis base sites. This combined structure behaves much like Frustrated Lewis pairs, serving to facilitate the activation of O<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, as well as C–C and C–H bonds. As a result, the defective MnO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> catalyst shows high catalytic activity (turnover frequency: 113.5 h<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>) and formic acid yield (>80%) comparable to noble metal catalysts for glycerol oxidation. The catalytic system is further extended to the oxidation of other polyols/sugars to formic acid with excellent catalytic performance.</jats:p>
title: Enhancing polyol/sugar cascade oxidation to formic acid with defect rich MnO2 catalysts
